items.title: Iran’s Ayatollah Ali Khamenei blames Trump for inciting anti-government protests
items.summary_auto: Iran’s Supreme Leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, has acknowledged that thousands of people were killed during anti-government protests over the last two weeks, but blamed the U.S. for the death toll. He also called President Donald Trump a criminal for supporting the protests, which have been countered by tens of thousands of pro-government demonstrators. The U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency said it has verified 3,090 deaths, including 2,885 protesters, and over 22,000 arrests.

items.title: Ottawa unveils next steps in its national gun buyback program. Here are the details
items.summary_auto: The federal government has unveiled the next steps in its national gun buyback program — and Canadians will have about two months to declare their interest in participating in order to receive compensation for turning in outlawed firearms.

items.title: European Union, South America's Mercosur bloc sign landmark free-trade agreement
items.summary_auto: The European Union and the Mercosur bloc of South American countries formally signed a long-sought landmark free trade agreement on Saturday, capping more than a quarter-century of torturous negotiations to strengthen commercial ties in the face of rising protectionism and trade tensions around the world.

items.title: Canada wants to be 1st in North America to build EV with Chinese knowledge: senior official
items.summary_auto: Canada wants to look at joint ventures and investments with China within the next three years to build a Canadian electric vehicle with Chinese knowledge, according to a senior Canadian official.

items.title: Potholes the size of a small bathtub on B.C.'s Coquihalla Highway concern drivers
items.summary_auto: A Kamloops, B.C., woman says she’s worried someone could die as a result of hitting one of several large potholes on the Coquihalla Highway, which connects B.C. 's Lower Mainland to the southern Interior.

items.title: Alberta counties, green power companies await new power rules
items.summary_auto: Construction on approved wind and solar projects in Alberta is on hold as developers await to see how planned changes to the province's power market would affect their business models. Rural politicians discuss the implications of potentially billions in lost investment.

items.title: How this Indigenous mask from B.C. inspired the Seattle Seahawks logo
items.summary_auto: Researchers at the University of Washington believe the inspiration for the NFL’s team logo, which consists of a profile of a raptor, is a transformation mask from the Kwakwakaʼwakw of northern Vancouver Island.

items.title: I lost my driver’s licence for a year. Everything went uphill from there
items.summary_auto: In 2024, Vivienne Steele had a medical change that resulted in her driver’s licence being suspended. Over the next year, she rode buses, bikes, walked or bummed rides around Whitehorse, and learned more about both her community and herself.

items.title: NASA rolls out giant rocket ahead of astronauts’ moon mission
items.summary_auto: NASA is preparing to send astronauts to the moon as early as next month, which will include Canadian Space Agency's Jeremy Hansen. But first they need to ensure the rocket and spacecraft are ready to fly.

items.title: Why do childhood vaccine recommendations differ across Canada — and around the world?
items.summary_auto: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention revised childhood vaccine recommendations earlier this month, but Canadian health experts don't think this country will follow suit. That's because public health bodies carefully consider the needs of their regions, taking into account demographics, budget restrictions and existing resources.

items.title: Russia’s anti-LGBTQ+ laws haven’t stopped fans there from embracing Heated Rivalry
items.summary_auto: Canadian series Heated Rivalry has become a global sensation, sparking conversations around sexuality, stereotypes and acceptance. In Russia, where it technically can’t even legally be watched, there are calls for it to be banned outright. But that hasn't stopped many Russian fans from showing their love for the series online.

items.title: Countries have gotten results after enriching the Trumps. Could Canada do the same?
items.summary_auto: Countries that have relied on traditional diplomacy to deal with the Trump administration have had less success than countries that have found ways to directly enrich the Trump family and those close to them.

items.title: 'Superagers' reveal how to stay sharp as you get older
items.summary_auto: People over 80 with memory of those in their 50s show less brain shrinkage and other differences. For a Canadian centenarian, the secret might lie in his passion for sharing a vocation turned hobby.

items.title: Trade trumps diplomatic tensions in B.C. premier's India visit
items.summary_auto: Before landing in India for a six-day trade mission, B.C. Premier David Eby's main objective was to pack in as many meetings and garner as much interest in his province's resources as possible. Less than a year ago, that would have seemed virtually impossible to achieve in a country that was deep into a tense diplomatic rift with Canada.

items.title: What can new polling tell us about the health of Canadian democracy?
items.summary_auto: Despite widespread concern about declining levels of trust, Canadian analytics firm Environics finds that overall levels of trust in many of the institutional pillars of this country's democracy — elections, the prime minister, Parliament, the Supreme Court — have been relatively stable over the last 10 to 15 years.

items.title: Niagara Falls helps hundreds of Kashechewan water crisis evacuees settle into the Ontario city
items.summary_auto: Hundreds of Kashechewan First Nation evacuees have arrived in Niagara Falls, one of the Ontario cities taking in people from the Cree community as it endures a water crisis. With 1,700 expected in the Niagara Region city alone, authorities and local Indigenous groups are doing everything they can to help them feel at home.

items.title: For these Montrealers, the Africa Cup of Nations represents home, love of soccer and unity
items.summary_auto: For nearly a month, Montrealers from African countries have been gathering in the city's cafés, restaurants, bars and the comfort of their own homes to support their respective teams in the 2025 Africa Cup of Nations, the continent's iconic soccer tournament  which ends Sunday.

items.title: 'Misdirected' passengers skipped customs after international flight landed in Ottawa
items.summary_auto: Ten Air Canada passengers left the Ottawa airport without clearing customs Sunday night, after arriving on an international flight from Cancun, Mexico.

items.title: Girls are banned from Afghan schools. Secret networks are teaching them anyway
items.summary_auto: Organizations are working hard to circumvent the Taliban's ban on higher education for women and girls, which has now been in place for over four years. One advocate says that women and girls have been 'unbelievably resourceful in finding workarounds.'

items.title: Why Donald Trump endorsed Canada's deal with China
items.summary_auto: Mark Carney's new deal with China — to lower tariffs on EVs, canola and other products — sparked fears that the U.S. would lash out at Canada. But President Donald Trump said the deal is a "good thing." Some experts think the Americans will use Canada's deal to help forge their own agreement with China.
